results.title: Half of mankind
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir, United Nations and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: This film deals with community development in Asia. The village is the unit of organization on which Asia rests, and it is the basis of community development. Three examples are shown: simple self-help in Cambodia; villages cooperating with the World Health Organization to run a health clinic in Afghanistan; interdependence of the agricultural and industrial communities in India, with cash crops providing capital for agricultural development and mechanized expansion of village crafts with the aid of electricity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ezra Mir, United Nations and Films Division, Government of India

results.title: Frank Eidlitz Design Centre
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: This film features flashing lights that may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy.

The Frank Eidlitz Collection contains the 16mm and 35mm film work of graphic designer and visual artist Frank Eidlitz (1923–1997), predominantly made during a Winston Churchill Fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge in 1966. The collection contains Eidlitz’s experiments with light, movement and technology in film.

This short film features Frank Eidlitz’s early experiments with light, colour and motion. Commissioned by the television network National Broadcasting Company (NBC) to reinterpret the station’s classic peacock logo, Eidlitz produced a series of film experiments with kaleidoscopic spinning lights.

To create these visuals, Eidlitz covered a series of disks with pieces of reflective paper and fluorescent colours, which he then placed on an apparatus that spun the disks at a high speed. The motion could be varied and stopped at any time, allowing the artist to create varying designs and images.

The film features coloured glitter, spinning lights and metallic reflective surfaces accompanied by the NBC peacock. As well as the disk experiments, the film features several of Eidlitz’s other visual experiments, including close-ups of moving liquid in glass prisms, thick daubs of paint and textured surfaces.
results.title_for_label: [Frank Eidlitz Collection: Frank Eidlitz Design Centre (original footage)]

results.title: Easy does it
results.creator_credit: Anthony Gibb, Don Anderson, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1967 film is a light-hearted look at the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back strain and injury. The film shows footage of factory and manual labourers handling various heavy loads, including using equipment to aid safe lifting. This footage is interspersed with examples of everyday strain such as women hanging out the washing and lifting a baby from a pram; and moments of slapstick comedy as a man struggles to carry his bride over the threshold of their house and a man lifts a keg of beer at a barbeque.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The notes accompanying this film indicate that the footage is taken while on holiday in Queensland in 1955.

This film opens with rural landscape scenes of lush vegetation with mountains in the background. We see pine trees, fence posts and wire as well as a small out-house type construction made of wood with a corrugated iron roof. It could be an outdoor toilet.

There is footage of various varieties of tropical fish including butterfly fish, and varieties of coral including brain coral and large shells. These scenes appear to be shot through glass, so they could be at an Aquarium or on a glass-bottomed boat.

We see scenes of a whale watching expedition, with the top of a whale just visible above the water. There is also some water ski action which seems to be taking place on a dam or weir.

Originally made using 16mm film.

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

The first half of this film is long scenes of the sea interchanged with a koala in a tree.

Later we see Edith Penington holding the koala which appears to be domesticated.

Much of the rest of the film is following this koala as it eats and climbs trees.

There is also a brief moment with a penguin and some sheep.

The film finishes with Edith Penington fishing.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 koala in a tree
00:02:17:00 Dr Penington climbing a tree to pat the koala
00:04:13:00 Edith Penington cuddling a koala bear as it is fed
00:04:35:00 the koala bear climbs into the trees
00:04:55:00 Dr Penington cuddling the koala bear and feeding it
00:06:20:00 penguin being released running to its burrow
00:06:23:00 Dr Penington climbs into a tree with the koala
00:06:38:00 Edith Penington fishing

results.title: Heart research
results.brief_description: David Crawford has always studied and worked in the field of science. With assistance from the Heart Foundation, it’s his work in public health research that provides the most satisfaction. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.creator_credit: Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja
results.credit_line:
Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Script: Courtney Collins with Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Sound: Left of Elephant Sound

Single-channel video

Approx. 5 mins

Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

constellations_primary.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_primary.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
This film comprises a slice of family life in suburban Melbourne.

The first scene shows children playing in their backyard under a homemade cubby house constructed of bed sheets, cardboard and possibly curtains. They play with long pieces of bamboo cane, running and dancing around the cubby house. We can see what is probably the rear of the house which is a mid-century modern style. The film shows backyard play equipment such as monkey bars and swings, and neighbouring houses appear in the background.

A young child dressed in cute overalls plays with a colourful ball and is joined by their mother and siblings. There is some lovely footage of the child standing on the garden path surrounded by flowers. A butterfly joins in as the toddler stops to pick some flowers.

The film shows some backyard above-ground swimming pool action. Children enjoy themselves duck-diving for coins, wearing diving masks and somersaulting under water. We see a delightful interaction between siblings as they sit in the sunshine and eat biscuits together.

We see a young child standing beside their mother. She is gardening dressed in her full-piece 1960s swimming costume.

Three children play together in a wading or paddling pool, filling it up with water from the nearby garden hose. They take great delight in creating a flood, squirting each other with water, splashing and jettisoning the water into the air. They play piggy-back in the pool, use plastic kickboards and sit in an improvised plastic boat.

The film shows scenes of children swimming laps in an outdoor inbuilt swimming pool which could be at St Catherine’s School, Toorak. We can see some impressive buildings in the background which could be a part of the school or neighbouring houses.

There is a lovely scene of a young boy riding his tricycle along a leafy suburban street, lined with large houses. The street could be Cleeve Court in Toorak.

We see a young girl playing on a swing surrounded by a beautiful garden in full bloom.

The film finishes with a trip to the country for horse riding lessons. We see the horses being saddled up while they stand under a Hills Hoist clothes line, and the children are taken through their rising trot and cantering paces. The horse riding instructors use wooden sign posts and mallets to mark out a course for the young horse riders.

This film shows great examples of fashion, including swimwear, children’s recreational activities including horse riding and swimming, play equipment, toys and architecture typical of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film

Selected Highlights list:
00:00:56:00 Children playing with long pieces of cane with mid-century modern house in background
00:03:36:00 Small boy and a butterfly on a garden path
00:05:29:00 Brother and sister sit by the swimming pool eating biscuits
00:07:43:00 Mother goes for a swim – good example of swimwear
00:08:35:00 Three children play in a wading pool
00:09:56:00 Children swim laps in an outdoor pool, perhaps at St Catherine’s School, Toorak
00:10:26:00 Children dive into an outdoor pool as above
00:10:37:00 Boy on tricycle riding down a street lined with grand houses, perhaps Cleeve Court, Toorak
00:11:25:00 Children play in wading pool with kickboards and improvised boat

The first scene shows children playing in their backyard under a homemade cubby house constructed of bed sheets, cardboard and possibly curtains. results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a schoolboy game of cricket being played on the turf wicket in the grounds of the Glamorgan Preparatory School in Toorak, Victoria. Glamorgan is the Toorak campus of the Geelong Grammar School in Geelong Victoria. The boys wear Geelong Grammar school caps. Behind the cricket pitch we can see the rooftops and chimneys of the grand homes of Toorak. There is a colourfully painted wall behind the cricketers depicting a scene of Governor Phillip raising the flag at Sydney Cove in 1788. A hand painted didactic says:
“Governor Phillip brought the First Fleet to anchor at Botany Bay but raised the flag at Sydney Cove January 26th 1788. This was the first Australia Day.”

We see the Glamorgan Vs Visitors scoreboard, runs being made, catches being taken and 4s being scored.

The film then takes us to a suburban backyard to show a young baby on a rug. There is some lovely footage of the baby trying to crawl, wearing a handmade necklace made from wooden cotton reels. The baby shares the backyard with other children who play on climbing equipment and engage with the baby.

We see a toddler dressed in rompers standing inside a playpen. The toddler pushes the playpen along from the inside, walking out onto a verandah. There is some delightful footage of a baby crawling along a garden path and playing in a container of water.

The film shows children playing and swimming in an above ground backyard swimming pool. They have kickboards and rubber rings which could be bicycle tyres. They take turns somersaulting into the water from the edge of the pool. After finishing swimming, and wrapped in towels, the children eat drum-stick style ice creams.

This film shows good examples of family at-home recreation and play equipment, including climbing equipment and a swimming pool. There are also examples of suburban architecture, children’s and babies’ fashion, baby paraphernalia such as a playpen, school sports playing fields and turf cricket.

This film was originally made on 16mm.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:25:00 School cricket match with painted Australia Day/Governor Phillip scene behind
00:03:52:00 Glamorgan score board
00:05:21:00 School boys playing cricket, umpire (teacher) and painted wall behind
00:06:50:00 Baby with necklace of wooden cotton reels
00:09:08:00 Toddler inside playpen, walking out onto the verandah
00:09:28:00 Toddler crawls across the verandah
00:10:51:00 Toddler in rompers crawling along a garden path to play in container of water
00:14:01:00 Children playing in backyard pool
